texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: author: Major Hayden date: '2023-11-19' summary: > October brings us the Halloween holiday here in the US and I set off on an adventure into some spooky and unsettling books. 👻 tags:
texts.text: author: Major Hayden date: '2023-11-19' summary: > October brings us the Halloween holiday here in the US and I set off on an adventure into some spooky and unsettling books. 👻 tags:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: books
texts.text: books

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: reading
texts.text: reading

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Reading allows me to travel to other places and times while also reducing my stress and helping me to think more creatively. Sometimes this leads me to wild fictional stories or takes me on a learning journey into history.
texts.text: Reading allows me to travel to other places and times while also reducing my stress and helping me to think more creatively. Sometimes this leads me to wild fictional stories or takes me on a learning journey into history.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (I  track my reading lists on Goodreads  if you want to see what I'm reading.)
texts.text: (I  track my reading lists on Goodreads  if you want to see what I'm reading.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In this post, I'll list the spooky books I read this October and hopefully you'll find at least one them interesting!
texts.text: In this post, I'll list the spooky books I read this October and hopefully you'll find at least one them interesting!

texts.label: title
texts.orig: The Cabin at the End of the World
texts.text: The Cabin at the End of the World

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My first book of the month was Paul Tremblay's  The Cabin at the End of the World . It's centered around a family with a small child that goes on a relaxing vacation in a lakefront cabin.
texts.text: My first book of the month was Paul Tremblay's  The Cabin at the End of the World . It's centered around a family with a small child that goes on a relaxing vacation in a lakefront cabin.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All is well until a friendly stranger named Leonard befriends the child, Wen, and his three fellow travelers appear. The travelers hold the family hostage and tell them that they have the key to save the world, but it's not as easy as it seems. There seems to be an unseen force that has some sort of control over the travelers. 🤔
texts.text: All is well until a friendly stranger named Leonard befriends the child, Wen, and his three fellow travelers appear. The travelers hold the family hostage and tell them that they have the key to save the world, but it's not as easy as it seems. There seems to be an unseen force that has some sort of control over the travelers. 🤔

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: My thoughts
texts.text: My thoughts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I thought I had this story figured out several times only to be proven wrong just as many times. There are so many themes in this book that tug at your emotions, including family, racism, homophobia, and socioeconomic differences. This book packs plenty of suspense, but the most frightening parts aren't supernatural or ghostly. The scariest parts feel centered around the essence of human nature.
texts.text: I thought I had this story figured out several times only to be proven wrong just as many times. There are so many themes in this book that tug at your emotions, including family, racism, homophobia, and socioeconomic differences. This book packs plenty of suspense, but the most frightening parts aren't supernatural or ghostly. The scariest parts feel centered around the essence of human nature.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although this felt like a quick read, it was intense in many places. I definitely enjoyed it and I was looking forward to seeing the movie adaptation,  Knock at the Cabin . The movie was done by  M. Night Shyamalan  (of  The Sixth Sense  fame) and I read that he changed the entire ending of the movie. 😞
texts.text: Although this felt like a quick read, it was intense in many places. I definitely enjoyed it and I was looking forward to seeing the movie adaptation,  Knock at the Cabin . The movie was done by  M. Night Shyamalan  (of  The Sixth Sense  fame) and I read that he changed the entire ending of the movie. 😞

texts.label: title
texts.orig: The Ruins
texts.text: The Ruins

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I moved onto something  completely different  next with Scott Smith's  The Ruins . The story takes place in Mexico with several people on a beach vacation. One of the tourists notes that his brother went to check out an archeological dig further into the countryside but never returned. The group eventually decides to go search for the missing brother as some sort of vacation adventure.
texts.text: I moved onto something  completely different  next with Scott Smith's  The Ruins . The story takes place in Mexico with several people on a beach vacation. One of the tourists notes that his brother went to check out an archeological dig further into the countryside but never returned. The group eventually decides to go search for the missing brother as some sort of vacation adventure.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The adventure turns ugly as they make their way to the country's interior. 😬
texts.text: The adventure turns ugly as they make their way to the country's interior. 😬

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: My thoughts
texts.text: My thoughts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You'll have a tough time finding the antagonist in this story until it's too late, but that's part of the fun. Every character in the group brings personality quirks and old baggage with them that impairs their judgement in different ways. This works well for some but not for others.
texts.text: You'll have a tough time finding the antagonist in this story until it's too late, but that's part of the fun. Every character in the group brings personality quirks and old baggage with them that impairs their judgement in different ways. This works well for some but not for others.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This book had several scary moments, but most of the horror came again from how humans interact with one another. As soon as someone (or something) else figures out how to exploit those against them, bad things happen.
texts.text: This book had several scary moments, but most of the horror came again from how humans interact with one another. As soon as someone (or something) else figures out how to exploit those against them, bad things happen.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This book was difficult to read because much of it was quite gruesome and brutal. It's definitely a book for adults only and you should be prepared to work your way through it.
texts.text: This book was difficult to read because much of it was quite gruesome and brutal. It's definitely a book for adults only and you should be prepared to work your way through it.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: The Troop
texts.text: The Troop

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Everything is fine with a scout trip to an island in Canada in Nick Cutter's  The Troop . Well, it's fine until a mysterious and incredibly hungry man suddenly shows up on the island. He looks a lot like he's dead already and the the leader of the scout troop, a medical doctor, is completely mystified by the man's condition.
texts.text: Everything is fine with a scout trip to an island in Canada in Nick Cutter's  The Troop . Well, it's fine until a mysterious and incredibly hungry man suddenly shows up on the island. He looks a lot like he's dead already and the the leader of the scout troop, a medical doctor, is completely mystified by the man's condition.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It goes downhill from there in a story told mostly through diary entries, newspaper clippings, and court testimony.
texts.text: It goes downhill from there in a story told mostly through diary entries, newspaper clippings, and court testimony.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: My thoughts
texts.text: My thoughts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Of all the books I read in October, this one scared me the most because it felt like it was entirely possible. There wasn't any part of the book that I looked at and said: "Oh, that could never happen." That's what makes this one so good.
texts.text: Of all the books I read in October, this one scared me the most because it felt like it was entirely possible. There wasn't any part of the book that I looked at and said: "Oh, that could never happen." That's what makes this one so good.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's suspenseful enough to keep you turning the pages but it's also plausible enough that you might find yourself wanting to wash your hands a little longer the next time you eat a meal. It feels a bit like  Lord of the Flies  mixed with a pandemic novel like  Station Eleven  or  The Stand .
texts.text: It's suspenseful enough to keep you turning the pages but it's also plausible enough that you might find yourself wanting to wash your hands a little longer the next time you eat a meal. It feels a bit like  Lord of the Flies  mixed with a pandemic novel like  Station Eleven  or  The Stand .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This one is also  very gruesome  in parts with some very difficult scenes to read.
texts.text: This one is also  very gruesome  in parts with some very difficult scenes to read.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This one was my favorite of the group by far.
texts.text: This one was my favorite of the group by far.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Devolution: A Firsthand Account of the Rainier Sasquatch Massacre
texts.text: Devolution: A Firsthand Account of the Rainier Sasquatch Massacre

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sasquatch is back in Max Brooks'  Devolution ! Told through the journals of a woman living in a remote town in Washington, this book covers a modern time where Mount Ranier erupted and caused lots of species to get on the move from their habitats around the mountain. Some of those creatures are the ones you'd expect, but some are ones you won't expect.
texts.text: Sasquatch is back in Max Brooks'  Devolution ! Told through the journals of a woman living in a remote town in Washington, this book covers a modern time where Mount Ranier erupted and caused lots of species to get on the move from their habitats around the mountain. Some of those creatures are the ones you'd expect, but some are ones you won't expect.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The small community is an experiment in green, off the grid living, and they are quickly tested by just about everything mother nature can throw at them. This includes some rather tall, furry, human-like creatures.
texts.text: The small community is an experiment in green, off the grid living, and they are quickly tested by just about everything mother nature can throw at them. This includes some rather tall, furry, human-like creatures.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: My thoughts
texts.text: My thoughts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This one felt scary due to the remoteness of the village and the unprepared people involved. Also, whether you believe in Sasquatch or not, this felt a bit more plausible than I expected.
texts.text: This one felt scary due to the remoteness of the village and the unprepared people involved. Also, whether you believe in Sasquatch or not, this felt a bit more plausible than I expected.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There were plenty of difficult to read scenes in here, but the gore was reduced compared to other books listed here. Much of the suspense came from how humans interact with one another especially when faced with an adversary that presents a unique set of challenges.
texts.text: There were plenty of difficult to read scenes in here, but the gore was reduced compared to other books listed here. Much of the suspense came from how humans interact with one another especially when faced with an adversary that presents a unique set of challenges.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This book was difficult to get into (it starts slow), but stick with it. It's a wild ride.
texts.text: This book was difficult to get into (it starts slow), but stick with it. It's a wild ride.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Tender is the Flesh
texts.text: Tender is the Flesh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Be prepared when you crack open Agustina Bazterrica's  Tender is the Flesh . Imagine a world where animals somehow contract a virus that they quickly spread to each other and to humans as well. Pets are banned and animals near cities are killed. The pandemic puts a significant dent in the human population.
texts.text: Be prepared when you crack open Agustina Bazterrica's  Tender is the Flesh . Imagine a world where animals somehow contract a virus that they quickly spread to each other and to humans as well. Pets are banned and animals near cities are killed. The pandemic puts a significant dent in the human population.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, with all of the animals either infected or gone, where do people get meat to eat? 🤔
texts.text: However, with all of the animals either infected or gone, where do people get meat to eat? 🤔

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: My thoughts
texts.text: My thoughts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This was by far the most challenging book to read out of the group because I honestly felt like I was going to be sick in places. The author doesn't set out for cheap scares or basic unsettling events -- there's something much deeper. It really makes you question how humanity operates and how quickly boundaries can shift when hunger becomes a problem.
texts.text: This was by far the most challenging book to read out of the group because I honestly felt like I was going to be sick in places. The author doesn't set out for cheap scares or basic unsettling events -- there's something much deeper. It really makes you question how humanity operates and how quickly boundaries can shift when hunger becomes a problem.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I had to take a lot of breaks with this book. It has some suspenseful parts but this book has a slow-burn horror feel that gives you hope, crushes that hope, and then starts the cycle once more.
texts.text: I had to take a lot of breaks with this book. It has some suspenseful parts but this book has a slow-burn horror feel that gives you hope, crushes that hope, and then starts the cycle once more.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I strongly recommend this book  for adults only  but I feel terrible recommending it at the same time. 😄
texts.text: I strongly recommend this book  for adults only  but I feel terrible recommending it at the same time. 😄

texts.label: title
texts.orig: What's next?
texts.text: What's next?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After all of that horror and unsettling fiction, I'm shaking things up for November. My current book is Larry McMurtry's  Lonesome Dove . So many people have recommended it to me as a great book about the American west and I'm enjoying it so far.
texts.text: After all of that horror and unsettling fiction, I'm shaking things up for November. My current book is Larry McMurtry's  Lonesome Dove . So many people have recommended it to me as a great book about the American west and I'm enjoying it so far.
